August 4, 2002: Fiction
THE REMNANT, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $24.99.) Volume
10 of the "Left Behind" series, in which the forces of good battle the forces of evil
after the rapture of the saved.
THE LOVELY BONES, by Alice Sebold. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) A 14-year-old girl
looks down from heaven as she describes what happens in the aftermath of her
kidnapping and murder.
THE BEACH HOUSE, by James Patterson and Peter de Jonge. (Little, Brown,
$26.95.) After his brother drowns in East Hampton, a law student seeks revenge
on the powerful people who he thinks are responsible.
SUNSET IN ST. TROPEZ, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Surprises await
a group of friends who decide to spend August on the Riviera.
THE NANNY DIARIES, by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus. (St. Martin's,
$24.95.) A satirical look at rich and powerful New Yorkers through the eyes of an
Upper East Side nanny.
AN ACCIDENTAL WOMAN, by Barbara Delinsky. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The
residents of a quiet New Hampshire town are stunned when a local woman is
taken into custody by the F.B.I.
THE EMPEROR OF OCEAN PARK, by Stephen L. Carter. (Knopf, $26.95.) The
patriarch of a black family, forced to withdraw from consideration for the Supreme
Court, dies under mysterious circumstances.
HARD EIGHT, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $25.95.) Stephanie Plum takes
time out from bounty hunting to search for a girl who has been abducted.
THE SHELTERS OF STONE, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $28.95.) Love and danger
in a prehistoric society.
THE DIVE FROM CLAUSEN'S PIER, by Ann Packer. (Knopf, $24.) A young
woman from Wisconsin, whose fiance has been rendered a quadriplegic, decides
to move to New York and start a new life.
GRAVE SECRETS, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner, $25.) The forensic anthropologist
Temperance Brennan goes to Guatemala to help families identify their dead and is
soon caught up in a missing-persons case.
IN THIS MOUNTAIN, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $25.95.) In the seventh book of the
"Mitford Years" series, Cynthia Kavanagh thrives in retirement while her husband,
Father Tim, grows restless.
FIRE ICE, by Clive Cussler with Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $26.95.) A mining
tycoon tries to overthrow the Russian government.
August 4, 2002
Non-Fiction
SLANDER, by Ann Coulter. (Crown, $25.95.) The lawyer and pundit enumerates
"liberal lies about the American right."
THE LOBSTER CHRONICLES, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $22.95.) The
author of "The Hungry Ocean" gives up swordfishing and moves back in with her
parents on the island where she grew up.
YOU CANNOT BE SERIOUS, by John McEnroe with James Kaplan. (Putnam,
$25.95.) The autobiography of the former tennis star and current commentator.
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at Republicans and Democrats,
corporate America and our "nation of idiots."
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
WHY I AM A CATHOLIC, by Garry Wills. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The author of
"Papal Sin" explains his beliefs while examining 2,000 years of church history.
THE RIGHT WORDS AT THE RIGHT TIME, edited by Marlo Thomas. (Atria, $25.)
More than 100 celebrities describe a turning point in their lives.
A MIND AT A TIME, by Mel Levine. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A professor of
pediatrics examines the learning patterns of children and the various ways in
which parents and other adults can help them succeed.
THE SEXUAL LIFE OF CATHERINE M., by Catherine Millet. (Grove, $23.) A
French intellectual recalls her erotic exploits.
TEN THINGS I LEARNED FROM BILL PORTER, by Shelly Brady. (New World
Library, $20.) A memoir of a man with cerebral palsy who worked as a door-to-
door salesman in Portland, Ore., for 40 years.
ONCE UPON A TOWN, by Bob Greene. (Morrow, $24.95.) The story of North
Platte, Neb., which mil-lions of American servicemen passed through during World
War II.
SIX DAYS OF WAR, by Michael B. Oren. (Oxford University, $30.) An account of
the Arab-Israeli war in 1967 and how it transformed the Middle East.
TUXEDO PARK, by Jennet Conant. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) The story of Alfred
Lee Loomis, a Wall Street tycoon who helped establish a top-secret laboratory at
M.I.T. during World War II.
